Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: A Hybrid Zone Lens on Rapid Speciation During Refugial Isolation in the Field Vole (Microtus agrestis)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hybrid zones are natural laboratories that allow researchers to identify the changes that have caused populations to diverge into different, reproductively isolated species. This project will investigate a hybrid zone where two historically isolated populations of field voles now interbreed. Researchers will sample multiple individuals across the hybrid zone and identify the genomic regions involved in the formation of new species. One graduate student and a number of undergraduate students from diverse educational, cultural, and economic backgrounds will be trained in cutting-edge genetic techniques. This research will also be used as an active learning tool during a course specifically designed for first-year undergraduate students from historically underrepresented groups in the biological sciences.

The vole genus, Microtus, is a model system to investigate the process of speciation because it has a diversification rate 60-100 times higher than other vertebrates. The distribution of genetic variation within the field vole (Microtus agrestis) has been heavily shaped by glacial cycles. The species includes distinct evolutionary lineages that survived in separate glacial refugia during recent glacial maxima and are highly differentiated. This research will focus on a hybrid zone between two of these lineages and use transcriptome sequencing to identify fixed genetic differences between them. These genomic regions will serve as targets for subsequent analyses of individuals from across the hybrid zone. Using genomic cline analyses that consider the genetic composition of individuals across this transect, researchers will characterize variation across the hybrid zone revealing loci that show restricted introgression. These loci will be considered candidate genes related to reproductive isolation responding to factors, such as selective differences associated with the differing environments of the hybridizing forms, and genetic incompatibilities between them. The results from these analyses will provide a conceptual and empirical groundwork for the genetic architecture underlying speciation driven by isolation in glacial refugia and provide a set of candidate loci to investigate speciation in other mammalian groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigates the genetic changes that occur during speciation, i.e. the formation of new species during the process of evolution. Understanding speciation is an enduring goal of evolutionary biology that connects small-scale evolutionary processes that cause differences between individuals and populations to large-scale evolutionary processes that lead to the distribution of species through time and space. The field vole is particularly suited for studying speciation because it is within the genus Microtus, which has been shown to have a speciation rate 60-100 times higher than other vertebrates.  Our project investigates a geographic region where two historically isolated populations of field voles now interbreed in an area known as a hybrid zone. Hybrid zones are natural laboratories that test whether the genetic changes that occur in isolation over many millennia can cause populations to diverge into different, reproductively isolated species. Just as crossing the reproductively isolated species of horses and donkeys leads to infertile, hybrid mules, analyzing hybrid zones allows researchers to examine the genetic changes that lead to reproductive isolation in wild animals.

Our research examines a hybrid zone between two field vole populations that were isolated because of past climate change due to glacial cycles. Genetic variation within the field vole has been heavily shaped by glacial cycles: the species includes distinct evolutionary lineages that survived in isolated populations and accumulated many genetic differences rapidly. This project aims to capture the very early stages of the speciation process, to try to understand what genetic changes are responsible for reproductive isolation that initiates the split between two separate species. By sequencing the genome of many vole populations across the hybrid zone, we can use genetic analyses to find regions of the genome that show signatures of reproductive isolation. This will allow us to pinpoint the exact regions of the genome that are important for speciation, giving us a group of candidate genes whose function we can understand as well. Our studies have generated 125 full field vole genomes across 13 populations in the hybrid zone, and this will contribute significantly to our understanding of the genes underlying speciation. Analysis of this type of sequencing data will enrich both the conceptual and empirical knowledge of the speciation process. This research has also trained a new generation of researchers in cutting-edge genomic techniques, including a graduate student, undergraduate student and international researchers, from diverse educational, cultural, and economic backgrounds. This research was also used as an active learning tool during an undergraduate course specifically designed for first-year students from economic, gender, ethnic, or cultural groups that are historically underrepresented in the biological sciences.
